issue.title: Future Covariates with changing values over time
issue.body:
Hello,

I am trying to use transformers such as TFT or TiDE for a forecasting task.
For this task, I am using weather data. Naturally, I use the historical weather data as past covariates and would like to use weather forecast data as future covariates.

I am not sure how to handle the future covariates in the models.

Let's say it is January 1st 00:00 and I have hourly forecast for the next 24 hours where the air temperature forecast for Jan 1st at 1pm is 0 degree for example.

My issue is that, those forecasts are updated through time and values can change for future (and overlapping) forecasts.
For example, the forecast at Jan 1st 12am (12 hours after) for Jan 1st 1pm is -5 degree.

How to deal with future covariate in this situation ? and how to tell the model that it can only access the next x data points from the future covariates (only the next 24h in the example above) ?

Thank you!

issue.title: Two time series of different frequency
issue.body:
Hello,
I'm using the TFT model; I have two series (target and covariates), each with a different frequency; the target series has a monthly frequency, whereas the covariates series has a daily frequency.
When I try to setup TFT model I got this error:

**The dataset contains past covariates whose time axis doesn't allow to obtain the input (or output) chunk relative to the target series.**

How can I fix it?

issue.title: Torch Forecasting Models -  time spans
issue.body:
Hello, 

I am exploring and experimenting with your truly amazing "the" arts and wonder about following (which is not described anywhere in docs or guides as far as I know):
1. I will use RNN as an example

2. We know from the design of RNN that batch size param is one of the more important ones as it is directly connected with gradient descent and general approch how we want to deal with a bias-variance trade off during training (fitting), e.g. https://machinelearningmastery.com/how-to-control-the-speed-and-stability-of-training-neural-networks-with-gradient-descent-batch-size/

3. While playing with your variation of RNN in darts lib I wonder how exactly do you combine training_length and input_chunk_length params with basic batch_size param?

4. I read your nice guide - https://unit8co.github.io/darts/userguide/torch_forecasting_models.html#top-level-look-at-training-and-predicting-with-chunks 

5. What I conclude from it is following: 
- Given provided batch_size → let's say 20, and 
- the training_length → assume of length 10 , together with 
- input_chunk_length, let's assume of 8
- For each batch pass the algo splits provided batch sample of 20 obs (defined by batch_size) to past and future whereas past data is where model fits and future data is where model computes objective function (e.g. RSS) in a fashion where training_length param takes different starting poits of sequence of 10 obs (from the sample size 20) and splits it to 8 past (defined by input_chunk_length  ) and 2 future. 
- Fit on 8, evaluate on 2 and do this 11 times as that is given by the limitation of provided sample (batch sample of length 20 in our example can provide 11 different samples of length 10 defined by the training_length).
- So that within each batch we have 11 fits and thus 11 RSS values. 
- If you crack the ts sequence then you can have much more than 11 fits inside 20 obs, but for the initial discussion I would assume the simpliest approach where you keep ts sequence withou shuffling.

6. So far so good as this approach is a standard cross-validation approach, however, where things get really unclear to me is a moment when I saw your examples of parametrization where you used batch_size = 8 and training_length = 24 and input_chunk_length =16 or so.

7. Another confusing part is in your docs → "Side note: Our *RNNModels accept a training_length parameter at model creation instead of output_chunk_length. Internally the output_chunk_length for these models is automatically set to 1." 

8. What is the reason of introducing new param training_length and "hide" output_chunk_length and set it to constat value of 1?  How this param setup works at the end? From this little side note it almost seems that training_length overrides batch_size and thus training_length is "your" batch_size with fixed value of  output_chunk_length  = 1 thus actually the whole "batching" or sampling of the total training sample is driven by training_length rather than batch_size. 

9. And to conclude further, the actual setup happens between training_length and input_chunk_length (whereas output_chunk_length = 1 in RNNModels) and thus batch_size is irrelevant for sampling in your param setup, thus it only serves as a signal to update NN weights when given batch_size value is reached. And reaching the batch_size value is from training_length sequential variantions as described above when algo computes RSS value and every time when new RSS values are equal to batch_size param is a moment when algo updates NN weights. 

Can you please clarify how algo works when input sample for given pass of training  (i.e. batch_size) is smaller than training_length and  even input_chunk_length ?

I played with different RNN setups with regards to these params and results are pretty different from each other and as a side note I am a ML guy developing own libraries and algos so I believe some docs upgrades are needed.

Thank you very much for the clarification.

issue.title: TFT custom dataset shape?
issue.body:
I'm new to this library and want to do forecasting on the following data shape:

```
input: train_X (n_samples, n_steps, n_features) (10,000, 36, 15)
labels: train_Y (n_samples, n_outputs) (10,000, 12)
```

This means I want to use the past `36` months and  `15` features available as input.

I want to predict the future `12` months. 

I want to use the TFT model, but I'm not sure how to do I set up my model config and timeseries data shapes.

Do I need to use `input_chunk_length=36`, and `output_chunk_length=12`?

And for the `fit` method:

`model.fit(train_y, past_covariate=train_X)
`

and for 'predict' 

`model.predict(n=12)
`

issue.title: [QUESTION] How does one deal with updating/republishing forecasts as historical future covariates
issue.body:
Hi Darts Team,

I understand that external forecasts can be used as a future and historical future covariates, but how does one incorporate the fact that forecasts are typically republished at a given frequency when making a backtest?

E.g. following the example of River flow forecasting at https://medium.com/unit8-machine-learning-publication/time-series-forecasting-using-past-and-future-external-data-with-darts-1f0539585993, let's say one wants to do a backtest applying rolling window predictions, and assume that there is a new rain weather forecast every day. 
How does one "use" the historical forecasts, such that the model will utilize the newest forecast at the prediction point, but not a forecast which hasn't been released yet at that time.
Put in other words, is it somehow possible to state the publish time of a historical future covariate, and instruct Darts to only use the information available at that time when making predictions in a backtest.

issue.title: [BUG] LinearRegressionModel can't predict, saying input X contains NaN despite having no missing value
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I am using a LinearRegressionModel to forecast a hierarchical, hourly demand dataset. The demand is intermittent as it has 2 kind of time periods: a period which always have zero demand and a period which always have more than 1 demand.

Therefore, I ensured that my dataset has time series index with hourly frequency before converting it into a darts time series. I filled all the missing values with 0.0 (float representation of 0) and thus there shouldn't be any missing value. The missing value ratio function provided within the darts library have also confirmed this:
![image](https://github.com/unit8co/darts/assets/59689052/b5fa7bfb-4459-4374-bee2-8c288b4eefee)

Thus, I proceed with using the data for modelling and prediction:
![image](https://github.com/unit8co/darts/assets/59689052/83f7c9d6-4721-4f4c-bf9f-3eebbc4419b4)

However, during prediction, I encountered an error saying that input X contains NaN:
![image](https://github.com/unit8co/darts/assets/59689052/a62bcad7-b5e0-49fe-b6ca-41b8b32b245a)
...
![image](https://github.com/unit8co/darts/assets/59689052/e6137958-4dc9-479c-a0af-801c1a4e3888)

**Expected behavior**
This shouldn't have had happened right? as I have already checked before that the input doesn't contain any missing value. Is there any solution to this? Thank you

**System (please complete the following information):**
 - Python version: 3.9.16
 - darts version: 0.24.0

**Additional context**
I cant share the dataset since it is strictly confidential. However, the dataset characteristic can be easily understood as the dataset is basically a hourly record of the amount of customers served by a business unit.

issue.title: [Help] Global Multivariate Forecasting
issue.body:
Hey there,

I'm having trouble with the global models, especially how to prepare the data and what to use for predictions. Maybe someone can point me in the right direction. I'm using the Walmart dataset from Kaggle right now.

What I've done so far is split the data before grouping with **from_group_dataframe** and then make separate time series grouped by "store" for each target and the convariates for both training and testing sets and scale them.

Problems seem to start with the scaler; when plotting both training and testing, in the end they both seem to be scaled differently. Am I supposed to fit the scaler on the whole dataset before splitting?

Also, regarding **past_covariates** in **predict** should this include the data for both the training and testing sets? When using the test set for the covariates (x_test), I've received an error that the data does not go back far enough.

For the series used in **predict**, I have already figured out that this needs to be the training set.

Big thanks for this package; the available models and data prep options look really nice, and I can't wait to try out more different things once I get this to work 👍 


```python

df_train = df.loc[df["Date"] < train_test_split_date]
df_test = df.loc[df["Date"] >= train_test_split_date]

y_train = TimeSeries.from_group_dataframe(df_train, group_cols="Store", time_col="Date", value_cols=["Weekly_Sales"],
                                         freq="W")
x_train = TimeSeries.from_group_dataframe(df_train, group_cols="Store", time_col="Date", value_cols=features, freq="W")
y_test = TimeSeries.from_group_dataframe(df_test , group_cols="Store",time_col="Date", value_cols=["Weekly_Sales"],
                                         freq="W")
x_test = TimeSeries.from_group_dataframe(df_test , group_cols="Store", value_cols=features, freq="W")

y_scaler_dataset = Scaler()
x_scaler_dataset = Scaler()

y_train = y_scaler_dataset.fit_transform(y_train)
x_train = x_scaler_dataset.fit_transform(x_train)

y_test = y_scaler_dataset.fit_transform(y_test)
x_test = x_scaler_dataset.fit_transform(y_test)

forecast_steps=10
epochs=200

model_BlockRNNModel = BlockRNNModel(
     model="RNN",
     input_chunk_length=15,
     output_chunk_length=forecast_steps,
     n_epochs=epochs,
     random_state=0,
 )

model_BlockRNNModel.fit(
    series=y_train,
    past_covariates=x_train,
    verbose=True,
)

pred_cov = model_BlockRNNModel.predict(n=forecast_steps, series=y_train, past_covariates=x_train )
}

y_test = y_scaler_dataset.inverse_transform(y_test)
y_train = y_scaler_dataset.inverse_transform(y_train )
pred_cov = y_scaler_dataset.inverse_transform(pred_cov)

```

issue.title: [Question] TFT Multi-targets: Quantile Regression, are samples generated independently or dependently
issue.body: Hello, I've been using darts tft model for about a week, and its been fantastic: much easier to use than pytorch-forecasting. My timeseries dataset has multiple targets, and I'm wondering that when I predict and set a sample size, are the samples generated independently or dependently. For example, I might have two target columns, Lebron James points and Anthony Davis points. I was wondering if the effect of Lebron James points also affects Anthony Davis' points. for example, Lebron James might score 50 points, which in theory should make Anthony Davis average to go down as its harder for him to score points as there are probably less scoring opportunities. If the multi targets are generated independently, then the sample of Lebron James points wont affect Anthony Davis points. I was wondering if there could be support created for targets that are generated dependently, or if you have any suggestions on solutions to this matter?

comment.body:
Hi @zachyattack23,

Would it be possible to share a code snippet with a dummy/public dataset so that we can offer an answer closer to your use-case?

issue.title: Feat/Example notebook for the regression models
issue.body:
Fixes #588, fixes #1289.

### Summary

Example notebook for regression models, covering both some basics and advanced features :
- basics about lags, forecast based on covariates only, component-specific lags
- impact of `multi_model` when `ouput_chunk_length > 1`, visualization of the data tabularization when `multi_model=False`
- darts probabilistic forecasting, including direct inference of the distribution parameters
- sklearn-like models: built-in and custom implementations
- external librairies
- brief section about explainability

The example are mostly illustrative : they were not optimized for accuracy but aim at displaying how the various features can be used and their impact compared to the default parameters. The dataset was not studied in depth to extract correlation and no observation about the data are made.

### Other Information

The notebook relies on a new dataset `ZurichEnergyConsumption`, accessible on the city website (15 minutes frequency). Weather information covering the same period can be added as covariates by loading the dataset with `EnergyConsumptionZurichDataset().load(with_covariates=True)`. Since the weather data had a hourly frequency, the energy series is resampled at this frequency when it's loaded with the covariates.

Since the dataset is updated in real-time, the period was limited to 2015-2022 in order to have a fixed hash value. The missing values are not filled automatically to give more freedom to the users.

comment.body: Check out this pull request on  See visual diffs & provide feedback on Jupyter Notebooks. --- Powered by ReviewNB

pull_request.title: Feat/Example notebook for the regression models
pull_request.body:
Fixes #588, fixes #1289.

### Summary

Example notebook for regression models, covering both some basics and advanced features :
- basics about lags, forecast based on covariates only, component-specific lags
- impact of `multi_model` when `ouput_chunk_length > 1`, visualization of the data tabularization when `multi_model=False`
- darts probabilistic forecasting, including direct inference of the distribution parameters
- sklearn-like models: built-in and custom implementations
- external librairies
- brief section about explainability

The example are mostly illustrative : they were not optimized for accuracy but aim at displaying how the various features can be used and their impact compared to the default parameters. The dataset was not studied in depth to extract correlation and no observation about the data are made.

### Other Information

The notebook relies on a new dataset `ZurichEnergyConsumption`, accessible on the city website (15 minutes frequency). Weather information covering the same period can be added as covariates by loading the dataset with `EnergyConsumptionZurichDataset().load(with_covariates=True)`. Since the weather data had a hourly frequency, the energy series is resampled at this frequency when it's loaded with the covariates.

Since the dataset is updated in real-time, the period was limited to 2015-2022 in order to have a fixed hash value. The missing values are not filled automatically to give more freedom to the users.

issue.title: Future Covariates with changing values over time
issue.body:
Hello,

I am trying to use transformers such as TFT or TiDE for a forecasting task.
For this task, I am using weather data. Naturally, I use the historical weather data as past covariates and would like to use weather forecast data as future covariates.

I am not sure how to handle the future covariates in the models.

Let's say it is January 1st 00:00 and I have hourly forecast for the next 24 hours where the air temperature forecast for Jan 1st at 1pm is 0 degree for example.

My issue is that, those forecasts are updated through time and values can change for future (and overlapping) forecasts.
For example, the forecast at Jan 1st 12am (12 hours after) for Jan 1st 1pm is -5 degree.

How to deal with future covariate in this situation ? and how to tell the model that it can only access the next x data points from the future covariates (only the next 24h in the example above) ?

Thank you!

comment.body:
Hi @lamolivier,

If you have overlapping weather forecast, you are responsible for preprocessing them before passing them to the model: you could concatenate the weather forecasts with chunks of the same length as `output_chunk_length`, take the average or combine them in a lot of other ways.

For deep learning models, it is not possible at the moment to specific different lags/input length for the target and the covariates: the model will look at `input_chunk_length` values in the past for the target and the past_covariates and `output_chunk_length` values in the future_covariates. So no, it's not possible to forecast a time horizon with shorter covariates.

With `RegressionModel` however, all the things that you described are possible: 
-  to indicate to the model that it's allowed to access only the next 24h of the weather forecast with respect to the forecasted period, you can create it with the argument `lags_future_covariates=(0,24)` (assuming a dataset with a hourly frequency). Note that you will have to provide the historical values of your future covariates to train the model.
- as long as the regression model is able to access the values corresponding to its lags for each forecasted period, you can obtain forecasts of any length but the quality might decrease if `output_chunk_length` is very large.

comment.body:
> and how to tell the model that it can only access the next x data points from the future covariates (only the next 24h in the example above) ?

Regarding this question, I meant: is it possible to predict for a time horizon that is larger than the time horizon of some available futures covariates ? (For example, I need to have predictions for the next 48h but only have access to 24h weather forecasts and 12h from another future covariates. The idea is that I don't want to limit the prediction time horizon to the smallest time horizon from future covariates)

issue.title: The dimensions of the series in the training set and the validation set do not match.
issue.body:
I want to apply an EarlyStopping to my model using val_loss or val_MeanAbsolutePercentageError but I keep getting this error:

ValueError: The dimensions of the series in the training set and the validation set do not match.

I already checked the dimensions, including width, and it is the same (value of 1).


```

from darts.models import TFTModel, ARIMA, RNNModel
from pytorch_lightning.callbacks import EarlyStopping
from torchmetrics import MeanAbsolutePercentageError

torch_metrics = MeanAbsolutePercentageError()

# early stop callback
my_stopper = EarlyStopping(
    monitor="val_loss", # "val_MeanAbsolutePercentageError"
    patience=10,
    min_delta=0.05,
    mode='min',
)
pl_trainer_kwargs={
      "accelerator": "gpu",
      "devices": [0],
      "callbacks": [my_stopper]
}

tft = TFTModel(
    input_chunk_length=336,
    output_chunk_length=24,
    hidden_size=64,
    lstm_layers=1,
    num_attention_heads=4,
    dropout=0.1,
    batch_size=16,
    n_epochs=100,
    add_relative_index=False,
    add_encoders=None,
    # loss_fn=MSELoss(),
    random_state=42,
    force_reset = True,
    save_checkpoints=True,
    torch_metrics=torch_metrics,
    pl_trainer_kwargs=pl_trainer_kwargs,
)
tft.fit(series=train_transformed, val_series=val_transformed, future_covariates=covariates_transformed, verbose=True)
```

comment.body:
You are right, now it is training well, thank you!
Exactly, maybe the error is not clear enough.

comment.body:
Hi @sjav96, you also have to pass `val_future_covariates` to `fit()` when using `future_covariates`. Can you try again and see if it fixes the issue?

Maybe we should catch that ourselves in the future and raise a more clear error.

issue.title: TFT Model not reproducible
issue.body:
I am trying to train a TFT model but have issues with reproducible results. If I create two tft models with QuantileRegression likelihoods with identical parameters (and same random state) and train & predict, I get different results. I set all seeds as recommended by pytorch (https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/notes/randomness.html) and the Darts  TFT tutorial. The longer I train the models (more epochs), the more profound the differences are. However if I make deterministic predictions with the MSEloss, the results are almost identical for the two models (approx. differences in the 6th position after the decimal point). Although I work with a custom dataset, I also encountered this problem with the AirPassenger dataset following the tft tutorial.

Also, I am wondering if it is possible to get reproducible results in the following scenario: I am training a model and call predict() one time. If I then rerun my script (training the model and calling predict one time) should the predictions be identical? In my case, they are different.

My code is from the TFT tutorial with the exception that I add a second model:

```
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from tqdm import tqdm_notebook as tqdm

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

from darts import TimeSeries
from darts.dataprocessing.transformers import Scaler
from darts.models import TFTModel
from darts.datasets import AirPassengersDataset
from darts.utils.timeseries_generation import datetime_attribute_timeseries
from darts.utils.likelihood_models import QuantileRegression

import warnings
import random
import os
import torch
import lightning.pytorch as pl
seed_value =1
random.seed(seed_value)
np.random.seed(seed_value)
torch.manual_seed(seed_value)
torch.cuda.manual_seed(seed_value)
torch.cuda.manual_seed_all(seed_value)
torch.backends.cudnn.deterministic = True
torch.backends.cudnn.benchmark = False
pl.seed_everything(seed_value, workers=True)

os.environ["CUBLAS_WORKSPACE_CONFIG"]=":4096:2"
os.environ["CUBLAS_WORKSPACE_CONFIG"]=":16:8"
os.environ["CUDA_LAUNCH_BLOCKING"] = "1"
torch.use_deterministic_algorithms(True, warn_only=True)

warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
import logging

logging.disable(logging.CRITICAL)
# Read data
series = AirPassengersDataset().load()

# we convert monthly number of passengers to average daily number of passengers per month
series = series / TimeSeries.from_series(series.time_index.days_in_month)
series = series.astype(np.float32)

# Create training and validation sets:
training_cutoff = pd.Timestamp("19571201")
train, val = series.split_after(training_cutoff)

# Normalize the time series (note: we avoid fitting the transformer on the validation set)
transformer = Scaler()
train_transformed = transformer.fit_transform(train)
val_transformed = transformer.transform(val)
series_transformed = transformer.transform(series)

# create year, month and integer index covariate series
covariates = datetime_attribute_timeseries(series, attribute="year", one_hot=False)
covariates = covariates.stack(
    datetime_attribute_timeseries(series, attribute="month", one_hot=False)
)
covariates = covariates.stack(
    TimeSeries.from_times_and_values(
        times=series.time_index,
        values=np.arange(len(series)),
        columns=["linear_increase"],
    )
)
covariates = covariates.astype(np.float32)

# transform covariates (note: we fit the transformer on train split and can then transform the entire covariates series)
scaler_covs = Scaler()
cov_train, cov_val = covariates.split_after(training_cutoff)
scaler_covs.fit(cov_train)
covariates_transformed = scaler_covs.transform(covariates)

# default quantiles for QuantileRegression
quantiles = [0.01,0.05,0.1,0.15,0.2,0.25,0.3,0.4,0.5,0.6,0.7,0.75,0.8,0.85,0.9,0.95,0.99,]
input_chunk_length = 24
forecast_horizon = 12
my_model = TFTModel(
    input_chunk_length=input_chunk_length,
    output_chunk_length=forecast_horizon,
    hidden_size=64,
    lstm_layers=1,
    num_attention_heads=4,
    dropout=0.1,
    batch_size=16,
    n_epochs=300,
    add_relative_index=False,
    add_encoders=None,
    likelihood=QuantileRegression(
        quantiles=quantiles
    ),  # QuantileRegression is set per default
    #loss_fn=torch.nn.MSELoss(),
    random_state=0,
)

my_model1 = TFTModel(
    input_chunk_length=input_chunk_length,
    output_chunk_length=forecast_horizon,
    hidden_size=64,
    lstm_layers=1,
    num_attention_heads=4,
    dropout=0.1,
    batch_size=16,
    n_epochs=300,
    add_relative_index=False,
    add_encoders=None,
    likelihood=QuantileRegression(
        quantiles=quantiles
    ),  # QuantileRegression is set per default
    #loss_fn=torch.nn.MSELoss(),
    random_state=0,
)
my_model.fit(train_transformed, future_covariates=covariates_transformed, verbose=True)
my_model1.fit(train_transformed, future_covariates=covariates_transformed, verbose=True)

pred_series = my_model.predict(n=1, num_samples=10)
pred_series1 = my_model1.predict(n=1, num_samples=10)`

```
Am I missing something obvious here? I use darts==0.26.0 and python 3.10.

comment.body:
Hi @sonja-kompzkfe, reproducibility should already be handled on the Darts and PyTorch Lightning side, so no need to manually seed.

Can you try after removing all the related lines up and including `torch.use_deterministic_algorithms`?

issue.title: [BUG] DLinear fails to predict >1 variates in presence of static covariates
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
 Predicting two or more variates fails if there are static covariates present and shall be used.

**To Reproduce**

```python
import pandas as pd
from darts.datasets import ETTh1Dataset
from darts.models import DLinearModel

series = ETTh1Dataset().load().astype("float32")

target = series["HUFL"].stack(series["LULL"]).with_static_covariates(pd.Series([3, 4]))
past_cov = series["MULL"]

model = DLinearModel(16, 4, use_static_covariates=True)
model.fit(series=target, past_covariates=past_cov)

---> RuntimeError: mat1 and mat2 shapes cannot be multiplied (32x2 and 4x8)
```

**Expected behavior**
 Not a crash, but nice forecasts.

**System (please complete the following information):**
 - Python version: `3.10.13`
 - PyTorch version: `2.1.0`
 - darts version: `0.26.0`

**Additional context**
Possibly related to #1873 and #2035.

issue.title: Fix NLinear normalization to support past covariates
issue.body:
Re-opening #1583 
(sorry made a bit of a mistake when working on that branch, decided a fresh fork & pr might be best)



### Normalization description from [original paper](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.13504.pdf)

NLinear: To boost the performance of Linear when there is a distribution shift in the dataset, NLinear first subtracts the input by the last value of the sequence. Then, the input goes through a linear layer, and the subtracted part is added back before making the final prediction. The subtraction and addition in NLinear are a simple normalization for the input sequence.


### Summary

current implementation of normalization follows the implementation [here](https://github.com/cure-lab/LTSF-Linear/blob/main/models/NLinear.py)

this implementation works when the number of covariates being predicted as our target variable is the same as the number of covariates in our input (prev comment in implementation is incorrect, will work when n_params > 1 if n_params = target covariates)

since self.n_params == the amount of covariates we are predicting for AND we know that they are ordered first in our tensor
`input_tensor = [batch,timesteps, input_dim/number of covariates]` we can slice the tensor to only include the covariates in our target tensor like so `last_seq[:,:,output_dim:]`



### Other Information

New to doing open source work, please let me know if theres more that I need to do!! This was something I found when working on one of my own projects.

<!--Thank you for contributing to darts! -->

comment.body: I think something went wrong here. I opened a new issue: #2035.

issue.title: [BUG] NLinear fails to predict >1 variates
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Predicting two or more variates fails.

**To Reproduce**

```python
from darts.datasets import ETTh1Dataset
from darts.models.forecasting.nlinear import NLinearModel

series = ETTh1Dataset().load()
series = series.astype("float32")

target = series["HUFL"].stack(series["LULL"])
past_cov = series["MULL"]

model = NLinearModel(16, 4, normalize=True)
model.fit(series=target, past_covariates=past_cov)

---> RuntimeError: The size of tensor a (3) must match the size of tensor b (2) at non-singleton dimension 2
```

It works perfectly fine with `normalize=False`.

**Expected behavior**
Not a crash, but nice forecasts.

**System (please complete the following information):**
 - Python version: `3.10.13`
 - PyTorch version: `2.1.0`
 - darts version: `0.26.0`

**Additional context**
Possibly related to #1873.

issue.title: Fix/operand error with encoders
issue.body:
Fixes #1875, fixes #1991

### Summary

When encoders are used to generate covariates, they have the minimum time requirements. In tabularization, an arithmetic operation on `Timedelta` and `pandas.offset` must be performed to realign the covariate and target time indexes. However, some frequencies (`'M', 'Y' and 'y'`) conversion to `Timedelta` are ambiguous ([pandas doc](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.to_timedelta.html)), causing the unsupported operand error.

To solve the problem for these specific cases, a temporary `DatetimeIndex` is created and the information is extracted without relying on the conversion (slower than the arithmetic operation).
